Heredity, CrashCourse: Filmography

Summary This video discusses the history of heredity, the work of Gregor Mendel, and the basics of classical genetics, including genes, chromosomes, polygenic traits, pleiotropic genes, and Mendelian traits.  Highlights Heredity is the passing on of genetic traits from parents to offspring. Gregor Mendel was the first person to study heredity in a modern way. Genes are sections of DNA that determine traits, and most physical traits are a reflection of multiple genes working together. Some single traits are decided by a single gene and are called Mendelian traits. The consistency of ear wax is a Mendelian trait determined by a gene on chromosome 16 with two alleles one for wet ear wax and one for dry ear wax.

In addition i learned what classical genetics is which is a branch of genetics based solely on visible results of reproductive acts. What i also  learn is that some plants have polyploid in them which is when they have more than 2 sets of chromosomes in each cell. One thing that i thought was important in this video is how everything adds up together. For example traits are described by the genetic information carried by a molecule called DNA. Then a gene is a hereditary unit consisting of DNA which occupies a spot on a chromosome which then determines a characteristic in an organism

My paper on biological inheritance:   Fruit flies can change over time. However they will just become different versions of fruit flies. They will never become bees or worms or lizards. Science, particularly biology and genetics, shows us that Fruit flies cannot become bees or lizards no matter how much time goes by. Fruit flies cannot become lizards because fruit flies do not have the genes for scales or other lizard parts. Same with bees.  Dogs have a lot of genes for a lot of different traits which we can select for(artificial selection). Dogs however do not have genes for feathers,scales, or gills. We can only select the genes that exist in the dog gene pool. Genes for feathers,scales,gills do not exist in the dog gene pool.  Bears have a lot of genes for a lot of different traits which nature can select for(Natural selection). Bears however do not have genes for poison glands,wings, or tentacles. Nature can only select the genes that exists in the bear gene pool. Genes for poison glands,wings, and tentacles do not exist in the bear gene pool. Octopuses and squids however DO have genes for tentacles.  A dog cannot evolve into a fish because dogs don’t have genes for fish parts.  That is why dinosaurs can’t evolve into birds. Reptiles do not have genes for feathers,beaks,or a bird respiratory system. You can’t express a gene that an organism does not have.  Rhino’s in the past had genes for fur. The fur genes got expressed and rhino’s grow fur(wholly rhino). Rhinos in the past however did not have genes for wings. Rhinos can never evolve into bats or birds.

+Kim Kelly Mendel's law of segregation states that a gene can have different alleles, or different forms of the same gene. The law of independent assortment states that the alleles of one gene sort into gametes independently of the alleles of another gene, aka sorting genes into gametes without alleles of another gene affecting it.

+Anahy Dihybrid crossing is when you calculate the possibility of a kid inheriting two traits, not one. Say you have alleles A and B and assume they follow the Mendelian pattern of inheritance (with no bullcrap like masking or complementation or w/e). Say you have two parents, both with an AaBb genotype. You want to find out the probabilities (or ratios) of each kid having a certain phenotype.   Sex linked genetics are when you have a trait present in one of the sex chromosomes. The only one I can think of is eye color in fruit flies. Say you have a wild type trait, W, which codes for red eyes, and a recessive mutant, w, which codes for white eyes. The allele is present on the X chromosome but not on the Y. So if you have a female fly (XX) with the genotype, Ww, it'll have red eyes. If you have a male (XY), it'll only have the genotype w because the gene is not present on the Y chromosome.
